intro: Bupleurum raminifolium, commonly known as the narrow-leaved bupleurum, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, branching stems and finely divided, feather-like leaves. Its small white or pale yellow flowers appear in late spring, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Bupleurum raminifolium is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to temperate climates.
